Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 09:30PM sueper13 wrote: Jen, It really does help. I was hesitant too, and cut the dosage in half and then half again while I was doing chemo--I was put on this drug for anxiety/obsessive thoughts as soon as I was diagnosed, and thought I should get off it as soon as I could.  So when I told my onc I had decreased the dosage she said, "And how are your hot flashes?" I answered, "You know, now that you mention it, they are horrible."  I didn't even know it was effective for hot flashes until that moment.   It can interfere with Tamoxifen, and there is one antidepressant (Effexor) which interferes less, which I am going to ask my onc about in december. I think it is worth it, but everyone has to make their own choices and decisions.  Cris, you're almost done!!!! YAY CRIS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 10:20PM sueper13 wrote: Karin, So good to see your smiling face.  Wish I got curls ;O(....mine is straight.  Really, really straight.  But it is thick.  And grey.  Oh, well. I have been so d.a.t., reading but not posting during the week now.  I am retiring in 19 days (!!!) and the round of luncheons and beers after work has begun....the days are full and the nights are too short.  My point is, I will agaain be posting here most days once I retire.  Don't forget about me, okay? The one year ago stuff: yeah.  Here's my theory. One year ago we all put our heads down and put one foot in front of the other and did what we had to do.  Maybe we didn't process our emotions at that time, enough or at all. (I know I didn't).  So now, every time a "one year ago today" comes up for me, I am feeling those emotions that I didn't process.  Just trying to respect those emotions, feel them, and let them go.  Talking about it helps.  Love you guys. Retirement date is April Fools' Day (I couldn't resist), and prophy mast with bilateral DIEP recon is April 15th.  I am thinking about it all, a lot.  Have waited what feels like my whole life to be paid to stay home, and a lot of people are asking me what comes next....what are you going to do after you retire? My answer has always been "Whatever I want to" but I know I will be doing some volunteering involving older people, and women having babies.  Maybe holding the preemies...I don't know, but something to give back.  I have always  been so blessed. Hope everyone has a great weekend,  Sorry for the ramble. Love, Sue

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2009 07:58PM sueper13 wrote: Cris, Thanks so much for the quotes.  It's 4:15 a.m. and I have gotten out of my warm soft bed for work for the last time.  It feels so good, and of course I will miss all the people, but I won't miss the bulls&*t. Today I will just be checking out and returning keys and ID badges (badges?!?) and hugging people goodbye for now.  Everyone says keep in touch but I wonder how many really will.  Another opportunity to find out who your friends are?  I am always surprised. I feel reflective on my life's work so far, and calm, and  ready for the next adventure.  I can't wait to see what happens next. Yesterday one of the controllers asked me if I wanted to come down and work airplanes this morning and I said, No thank you.  I lost my medical a year ago because of bc, and I did not know the last time I worked airplanes was the last time.  That's how I want to leave it, sort of, I went out at the top of my game. I will miss feeling like I am one of the few who can do my job (feeling important).  I know I am still important, just not sure how it;s all going to fit together now, I just know it WILL. Thanks May women for listening. My cousin, Mary Ann, who had been an alcoholic for as long as i can remember, died in her sleep night before last. She was 46. I am so, so sad.  We grew up together, she always looked up to me, we talked on the phone every couple of weeks, and every time I went home she made time for us to get together just me and her. I will miss her forever. And I am angry at the waste. I will be traveling tomorrow thru Sunday for the  funeral and will probably be out of  touch.  Again, thanks for listening.  I love all of you and wish we could do a group hug this morning, I could sure use one. Love, Sue

Posts.Content: May 17, 2008 04:03AM - edited May 17, 2008 04:04AM by sueper13 Angie, Can't tell you what it was like to have a port installed, because I got mine the day of my mastectomy (We knew I'd need chemo).  I do second the opinion that it makes it all easier and less painful.  I also have the creme that numbs the port site, put it on 30-60 minutes prior to chemo and cover with saran wrap--it works well.  I don't even feel it when they access the port, and I also don't notice the bump of it anymore.  Sure I can reach up there and feel it if I want, but I can also reach up and touch my mast scar if I want.  There is no shortage of reminders for us all that we have or have had bc. I was also afraid the port would hit right where a bra strap goes but it doesn't hurt even if the strap moves over on it once its healed, I'd say about a week post-surgery.  Good luck and peace with your decision. Love, Sue

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 03:31AM - edited May 27, 2008 03:33AM by sueper13 bcs75, That is a greyhound next to me in the picture.  Her name is Lois, and she is just the sweetest creature.  My son rescued her. Turns out they make wonderful pets--they go outside and run like the wind for five minutes (and it's a JOY to watch them run) and then they are ready for a three hour nap!!! And she is sossosososooo silky.  She's technically my son's dog but it's turning out that where you see her in that picture is where she really likes to be....don't know how that will turn out as he is nineteen and will be leaving home soon and thinks he is taking her with him. We also have a husky mixed with we don't know what--she is about 1/2 size, with husky markings, medium thick hair and a tail that bends back out over her back--and beautiful ice-blue husky eyes.  Her disposition is sort of like a small, angry Latina, but she is sweet.  TAC is Taxotere, Adriamycin and Cytoxan.  I am getting that as well.  I think it's one of the more aggressive chemo regimens, but my cancer was grade 3. But, I am only having six treatments so I guess it all averages out?  Roberta, I also miss my morning coffee, and Nancy, I miss all kinds of food. I just figure if I can't taste it anyway, it's a great opportunity to eat healthy--lots of steamed veggies and lean protien. I have also pretty much been able to walk about four days a week or more and that seems to really help me with my particular emotional symptoms.  I haven't had a period since before my surgery April 2nd, which is kind of weird since I had one due between surgery and the start of chemo--but I can really tell I am in chemopause, I guess that's what this is, and where a lot of the emotional symptoms are coming from for me. We are all going through a very emotional and trying experience anyway, as women we try to do everything and are usually quite able to pull it off, and losing that ability is hard enough without adding mood swings and hot flashes to the mix.   My heat tolerance is ZERO and my poor son and his girlfriend are lying around the living room in blankets all the time while I am nearly perishing of heat. Anyway, bcs glad your cold is better and hope you  got back to sleep, I am off to work today and actually get to argue the ATC rules with theorists in headquarters on a conference call this morning.  I have the advantage because I have worked in the field for thirty years and have a better grasp of the rules......so cheer me on girls as I fight for the poor beleaguered understaffed air traffic control ranks today!!! I hope I win the argument!! (Please, God, don't let chemobrain make me forget what the argument was about...) Love, Sue

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2008 08:50PM sueper13 wrote: Hi all, hello again otter!  I am stalking you! I saw the oncologist today, whom I loved.  I will be having TAC X 6 every three weeks starting on April 24th.  The thing I didn't expect is she wants to then do six and a half weeks of radiation.  I was PLANNING (man plans, God laughs) once recovered from chemo to have my preventive mast with reconstruction and was considering TRAM flap.  Hadn't done a great deal of research because that is down the road and I have plenty to keep my obsessive, anxious brain busy right now.  The rads have implications as far as recon goes.  I don't want to do the saline implants because they are in a silicone envelope and the idea just feels creepy to me.  Anyway, the onc said she has seen a lot of women be unhappy with their results of TRAM flap and there is a 30% rate of permanent complications.  So I thought I was really attached to this idea of reconstruction with a tummy tuck, but now I find myself feeling--I just want to be here, I don't care if I just don't even have any reconstruction done.  Also the onc wants me to have the BRAC test.  I talked to my sister who discussed it with her GYN (she has always had lumpy breasts like I always did and has had several biopsies through the years) and her doctor told her she needed to have the BRAC test now and if it's positive she wants her to have a double mast and full hysterectomy.   So it's been an eventful day.  I also have long hair which I have always considered my best feature--I'm probably not doing the wig thing because it will be Texas in the summertime for me and it gets VERY hot.  I may change my mind, I have never even had my hair colored and I find myself realizing I have always wanted to be a redhead..........we'll see. Roberta, you and I are having the same treatment and we start the same day.  So, hello April chemo buddies!!! Sorry we all have to be here but glad we have each other, Sue

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 10:20AM sueper13 wrote: ellenoire, you have had the worst time with the IMHO worst type of distressing side effect.  I am so sorry that you have had to go through that. roberta, work went okay, although the emotional stuff still catches me by surprise.  I was an air traffic controller for thirty years, two years ago I took a job in Quality Assurance, I work at Dallas/Ft.Worth TRACON(that means the radar room), it is a great job.  I took the office work because my then-16-yr.-old was several steps down the wrong path and I needed to be home at night, and found that I was fascinated by the work and good at it.  I investigate pilot and controller mistakes, emergencies and other events.  Before breast cancer, I still maintained my currency in the radar room--actively worked airplanes, but was only required to do that eight hours each month.  I was winding down, aging out, and that was okay. ATC is a young person's job, it always will be.  So when I got to work yesterday, my colleagues had prepared a replay of my last three sessions of working live traffic---which I didn't know at the time were the last ones.  (You can't control live traffic and take any drugs at all--I am now what is referred to as medically disqualified because of the bc diagnosis and the treatment).  It was a really sentimental, keepsake-y thing to do and it made me cry.  Also they had put the following sign on our office door, which we keep closed--"One of our workers is immunosuppressed.  If you or someone in your family is sick, please visit this office at another time.  Thank You." Keep in mind these are low-tech, cro-magnon men who talk about football and guns.  I feel so special.  So that was my first day back at work. Nancy, good luck with PET scan.  Hope everyone has a good Friday!! Sue

There is this place I go that has something called the Ultimate pedicure--you go in and they put you in this huge recliner, give you an eye mask, snip fresh lavender to relax you....then there's lots of exfoliating (see, Noelle, I am a good girl), lotions, and the usual pedicure-ish scrubbing and buffing, then they polish the toenails.  Then they snip fresh eucalyptus to revive you (I always go to sleep). It is wonderful......... Off to Pittsburgh tomorrow to get my baby dogs.  I probably won't post for a couple of days as we are just flying up tomorrow and back on Thursday, and I have to work Friday.  I kind of understand now why Nicki only posts on the weekends.... Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 07:29AM sueper13 wrote: Viv, Otter, et al--I want to share my first sight of the new me,  I was still in hosp, the nurse told me I could take a shower, and I knew my husband was on the way.  I waited.  When he got there, I told him we could look now, and that I then wanted him to help me take a shower. We went in the bathroom and closed the door.  I took off the bra, and removed the gauze which was just lying on top, and we both looked.  I don't remember exactly what he said, (morphine pump) but he touched me, and I believe it was one of the most beautiful moments of our almost 30-year marraige.  He was all for the eventual bilat mast with eventual reconstruction, I just had the left one removed and we are waiting for chemo.  I have also been going around flat on one side with loose clothing, I am only 6 days post-surgery (My best friend refers to this look as "gypsy casual").  Otter, I'm going for the IPEX bra with a puffy as well, I think.  I'm only going to wear it when I need to power-dress, though.  I have this feeling of, "here it is, deal with it". I am also going this weekend for a haircut, as short as I can stand.  I have always felt that my hair was my best feature, it is long, curly and a darkish red-blonde. The haircut will be a baby step.  The most wonderful part of this sh&*tty experience so far has been all the support from family, friends and co-workers. I work in a male-dominated field (air traffic control) and all these tough, silent guys have been calling my cell phone to check on me and tell me they hope I'll be back soon and they are praying for me--it's a real wakeup call to realize one is loved by so many people. I also have the weird underarm thing and a surprising amount of pain still.  An area down the back of my arm that was numb got feeling back yesterday--and IT HURTS! But so far my BS has been generous with the pain meds. I will see her on Thursday.  Did anyone else get a sheet of exercises to do?  I did, but nobody told me how many to do or how often--I went for it right away and did too much, woke up in the night in EXTREME pain.  I've toned the repetitions down and started walking again, just 30 minutes helps so much.  I live in Texas and the weather is perfect right now.  Anyway, that's my accepting the new me so far.  The support and information on these boards has been invaluable to me. Thanks, Sue

Posts.Content: May 3, 2008 03:34PM sueper13 wrote: revkat, roberta and Angie, Thanks for your support.  I just woke up and feel a bit better, I will sure be glad when my coffee tastes normal again.  Waiting for things to get better has never been my forte.  I worked for thirty years in a stressful, immediate-results, prove-yourself-every-day type job, (Air Traffic Control), for the past fifteen was at the top of my profession (worked at Dallas/Ft. Worth airport), and here is what I am used to--when I say the words, immediate action happens.  I have had to learn through the years to turn that off when I am dealing with people instead of airplanes, but letting go of that CONTROL is what I am so struggling with in this.  I KNOW in my head that the sooner I can let it go the faster I will feel better, but my instinct, my reflex, my conditioned response, is to reach for that ILLUSION of being in control of events.  My youngest son was involved with drugs and a year ago we sent him to rehab, got through it with lots of family counselling which has made us a stronger family.  We discovered through this counseling that I have lots of issues around---wait for it---BEING IN CONTROL.  My son, Sam has been clean and sober for one year just last week, I am prouder of him than I have ever been of anyone, and I have so much to be thankful for. Usually I am so good at finding the good side in things and looking for the silver lining and it's not as if life hasn't handed me some hard times before.  I guess it's just different when you feel you have lost your health, your very ability to just feel good and as much as you tell yourself it is temporary, it becomes like chronic pain and begins to wear on you. But  I just woke up, had a restful night's sleep, it's a brand new Saturday and I actually feel like maybe doing some light housework and inviting a friend over to spend some time this afternoon--thanks for listeining I would go nuts if not for these boards.  No one who hasn't been through this can understand the feelings. Thanks and hugs and a beautiful Saturday to all, Sue

It really sucks that nothing tastes excellent anymore.   About the mouth thing--I'm getting Adriamycin, and they have me chew ice the whole time it is being infused.  This is supposed to help with the mouth stuff.  But i think the Taxotere also causes a mouth thing with my taste buds that starts about day 8---and lasts through about day 13 or 14.  Just a burny feeling like Sandy described, and no taste buds. Really am sick of it after only 2 tx.  I wonder if keeping a cool mouth during the taxotere would help? New se--insomnia.  Do I add another drug,  or just suffer and adjust?  I know, I'm whining, but I am a great sleeper when i am not doing chemo.  So another thing I have always taken for granted is just gone--whine, whine. I didn't win the argument, but I forced a very high member of management to put his arbitrary interpretation of the rules in writing instead of just making a verbal pronouncement with no accountability.  It was very technical and dangerous, but I find that since my priorities have changed and I sort of realize what is important that all of a sudden I am fearless and effective in this arguing--because I could care less what they think of me.  I have decided to retire at the end of November and I JUST DON'T CARE like I used to!!!!  Puts one in a unique position of power.....and I confess that I have ALWAYS enjoyed a good argument!!! Off to try again to get back to sleep............. Love, Sue

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 03:54PM sueper13 wrote: Nancy, I noticed the same thing with the neulasta/taxotere pain--have a good friend with the same type of saline pool.  Amazing.  I go back there every morning and swim for 1/2 hour--it's also good for  lymphedema prevention, my LE therapist says walk forward and pull back with your arms, walk backward and pull forth with your arms--improves the muscle and joint pumping for managing the fluid in your arms. Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 11:54PM - edited Oct 14, 2011 11:55PM by sueper13 Amy, There is no such thing as nosey on this web site. Thanks for the hugs!!  I am a bit of a surgery veteran. This operation was relatively easy, although waking  up afterward with the full pain (you know how they have to wake you up first before they can treat your pain?) was pretty painful.  I didn't cough if I could help it, although holding a pillow there if I absolutely had to cough helped.  I was in the hospital for two days.
